message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and diagnostic findings are consistent with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), a common condition in premature infants. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug used to close PDA in premature infants. Methadone is used to treat withdrawal symptoms in neonates born to opioid-dependent mothers. Caffeine is used for apnea of prematurity. Alprostadil is used to maintain ductal patency in certain congenital heart defects, but it is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and diagnostic tests suggest that the infant has patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), and Indomethacin is used to treat PDA in premature infants. Methadone is a medication for pain management, caffeine is for apnea of prematurity, and alprostadil is used to keep the ductus arteriosus open in certain congenital heart defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant’s clinical presentation and echocardiogram indicate Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug used to treat PDA in neonates. Methadone is an opioid used for pain management. Caffeine is used for apnea of prematurity. Alprostadil is a medication used to keep a patent ductus arteriosus open in infants with certain congenital heart defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and echocardiogram suggest a patent ductus arteriosus which can be treated with indomethacin. Methadone is used for pain management, caffeine is used for apnea of prematurity, and alprostadil is used for certain types of congenital heart defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and test results suggest that the newborn has patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), a condition where a fetal blood vessel fails to close after birth, causing excess blood flow to the lungs and heart. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can help close the PDA. Methadone, caffeine, and alprostadil are not used to treat PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), a condition where the connection between the pulmonary artery and the aorta doesn't close as it should after birth. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that is commonly used to close PDA in preterm infants. Methadone is a narcotic analgesic that may be used for neonatal abstinence syndrome. Caffeine is a stimulant used to treat apnea of prematurity. Alprostadil is a prostaglandin E1 analog used to keep the ductus arteriosus open in certain heart conditions, which is the opposite of what is needed in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and diagnostic tests suggest that the baby has patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), a common finding in premature infants. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can help close the PDA. Methadone and caffeine are not appropriate for this condition, and Alprostadil is used to keep the ductus arteriosus open in certain cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn’s symptoms and findings suggest patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which is a common condition in premature infants. Indomethacin is commonly used to treat PDA in premature infants. Methadone and caffeine are not used to treat PDA, while Alprostadil is used for a different type of cardiac condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest that the infant has patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which is causing congestive heart failure. Indomethacin is a prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor that can help close the PDA. Methadone and caffeine are not appropriate for this condition. Alprostadil is a prostaglandin E1 analog and is used in the treatment of some types of congenital heart disease, but not specifically for PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest that the baby has patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a medication used to close PDA in preterm infants. Methadone and caffeine are not appropriate treatments for PDA. Alprostadil is used to treat congenital heart defects with inadequate oxygenation of the blood, which is not the case in this scenario.
